search_input:
One night when I went out to drink water from the garden tap, I heard a long-haul truck barreling along a distant freeway, and another time, as steam rose around my dishwater, I felt the floor rumble with a passing train. The total whiteness is an effacement, an obliterationa neutral element, like a road leading to a place of rest. It is as if one were in a cavern, hidden away, a place where one rediscovers ones origins and roots. They evoke the idea of a place beyond, a place to which one might aspire. They draw one towards a place that, ultimately, one is perhaps not allowed to enter. *The whiteness is a threshold, a boundary beyond which one cannot proceed, though one may feel an irresistible urge to cross it. It is as if one were standing at the edge of a great precipice, the void stretching out before one like an abyss. The whiteness is a silence that swallows all sound, a stillness that freezes all movement.*

It is as if one were standing at the edge of a great precipice, the void stretching out before one like an abyss. The whiteness is a silence that swallows all sound, a stillness that freezes all movement.
